title: 110_hr4063
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Restitution for the Exonerated Act of 2007" and authorizes a grant program. The Attorney General is authorized to award grants to organizations providing support services to exonerees for one-year periods, renewable at their discretion. Emergency grants may also be awarded to address immediate systemic issues in exoneree support services. An emergency grant can be awarded to eligible organizations to address immediate support service needs for exonerees in a region for up to 6 months, and it is not renewable. Each organization can only receive one emergency grant under this provision. SEC. 3. GRANT USES.

An eligible organization must use the grant for a program providing support services for exonerees, including employment training, vocational training, education, health care, mental health services, housing assistance, substance abuse training, legal assistance, children and family support, and other services as determined by the Attorney General. The grant can also cover administrative expenses like staff salaries, research, and training. To apply for a grant under this Act, eligible organizations must submit an application to the Attorney General describing the program, long-term strategy, collaboration with agencies, and evaluation measures. The Attorney General will review applications every six months. The Attorney General will review grant applications every six months and prioritize organizations serving regions with the greatest need for exoneree support services. SEC. 5. REPORTS. Eligible organizations must submit yearly reports to the Attorney General detailing the program funded by the grant and evaluating its effectiveness. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, an "eligible organization" is defined as a nonprofit with experience in providing support services to exonerees, or the capacity to do so as determined by the Attorney General. An "exoneree" is someone convicted of a crime punishable by at least one year in prison, who has served at least 6 months in prison as a result. The term "factually innocent" refers to an individual who has been convicted of a crime but has been proven innocent through a court finding, a pardon from the Governor, or a court vacating or reversing the conviction. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $1,250,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2008-2012 to carry out this Act. Amounts available until expended.
